block.p: Bush and Cheney Chide Democrats on Iraq President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney aggressively challenged the motives of Congressional Democrats, accusing them of political opportunism, as the House and Senate prepared to consider a war spending bill that would order troops to be withdrawn from Iraq beginning later this year.

An Islamic Candidate in Turkey Turkey's ruling party chose a presidential candidate with an Islamic background, a move that will extend the reach of the party -- and the emerging class of devout Muslims it represents -- into the heart of Turkey's secular establishment for the first time.

Somali Profiteers Fuel Chaos Profiteers in Somalia have helped further the chaos there, feeding off the anarchy and teaming up with clan fighters and radical Islamists to try to bring down Somalia's transitional government, some Western security officials say.

Rebels Raid Ethiopian Oil Field Separatist rebels stormed a Chinese-run oil field in eastern Ethiopia, killing more than 70 people, including 9 Chinese workers, in one of Ethiopia's worst rebel attacks in years.

U.S. Mining Company Acquitted An Indonesian court acquitted Newmont Mining Corporation, the American mining giant, and one of its senior executives of charges of polluting a bay with toxic waste from a now defunct gold mine, in a case that became a litmus test of foreign investor confidence in Indonesia.

OSHA Leaves Safety In Hands of Industry Since George W. Bush became president, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration has issued the fewest significant standards in its history, public health experts say. The only significant health standard it issued was ordered by a federal courtand has imposed only one major safety rule.

Indian Women Voice Concerns Native American women are voicing growing anger at what they call their disproportionate victimization in crimes of sexual assault, most often committed by non-Indians, and attitudes and laws they say deter many from even reporting an attack.

Efforts to Improve Schools Bill Gates and Eli Broad two of the most important philanthropists in American public education, have pumped more than $2 billion into improving schools. But dissatisfied with the pace of change, they are now joining forces for a $60 million foray into politics in an effort to vault education high on the agenda of the 2008 presidential race.

New Planet May Be Earthlike A team of European astronomers have discovered a planet five times as massive as the Earth orbiting a dim red star known as Gliese 581, calling it the most enticing property found outside our solar system.

Care of Mentally Ill Inmates Under Review in New York New York State will more closely monitor its use of solitary confinement for mentally ill prison inmates under the terms of a legal agreement scheduled for review by a federal judge on Friday.

Bringing Youth Back to S.I. Staten Island could reverse the flow of young people leaving the borough with new zoning rules to entice developers to build lower-cost apartments close to the ferry, according to the Center for an Urban Future, a public policy group. B1

Studying the Mexican Model Mayor Bloomberg and a group of City Hall officials are in Mexico to study an antipoverty program that gives cash rewards directly to women and children. The program is a model for one the mayor hopes to start in New York. B1

Toyota Sales Overtake G.M. As February sales numbers confirmed that Toyota had surpassed General Motors as the world's largest automaker, Detroit reacted with a mix of resignation and discussion about what went wrong and how to regain its global leadership.
Apple Executives Face Suit Federal securities regulators brought a civil suit against two former Apple officers for a stock options backdating scheme.

Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd.
